statement.tex: %text Form the differential equation of the family of circles in the second quadrant and touching the coordinate axes. %

step.context: %text What is the equation of a circle with radius $r$, touching both co-ordinate axes and in the second quadrant. %
step.reason: %text A circle with radius $r$, touching the axes and in the second quadrant would have its center at $(-r, r)$ and therefore its equation would be, $(x+r)^2+(y-r)^2=r^2$. %

step.context: (x+r)^2+(y-r)^2=r^2 \\ %text If the above equation is differentiated once, what is $r$ in terms of $x$, $y$ and $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ ? %
%text We have $r=\dfrac{x+y y'}{y'-1}$. In order to get the final differential equation, we need to eliminate $r$. How can we do this? %
step.tex: %text Substitute $r=\dfrac{x+y y'}{y'-1}$ in the original equation $(x+r)^2+(y-r)^2=r^2$. %
%text Differentiate $r=\dfrac{x+y y'}{y'-1}$ w.r.t $x$ in order to eliminate $r$. %
step.reason: %text We do not require to differentiate again since we can get a first-order differential equation simply by substituting $r$ into the original equation of the circle. %

step.context: \text{If }r=\dfrac{x+y y'}{y'-1}, \text{ where }y'=\dfrac{dy}{dx} \\ %text is substituted back in the original equation of the circle, what is the outcome? %
\text{If }r=\dfrac{x+y \dfrac{dy}{dx}}{\dfrac{dy}{dx}-1} %text is differentiated to eliminate $r$, what is the outcome? %
step.reason: r=\dfrac{x+y \dfrac{dy}{dx}}{\dfrac{dy}{dx}-1} \\ %text Since the left-side of the equation is constant, its derivative would be zero. Therefore we can apply Quotient Rule and equate the numerator of the derivative of the right side to zero. % \begin{align} &{\small\left(\dfrac{dy}{dx}-1\right)\dfrac{d}{dx}\left(x+ y \dfrac{dy}{dx}\right)=\left(x+y \dfrac{dy}{dx}\right) \dfrac{d}{dx}\left(\dfrac{dy}{dx}-1\right)} \\ &{\small\left(\dfrac{dy}{dx}-1\right)\left(1+y \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}+ \left(\dfrac{dy}{dx}\right)^2\right)= \left(x+y \dfrac{dy}{dx}\right)\left(\dfrac{dy}{dx}\right)^2} \end{align}
